meanings.definition: A Swahili term of respect for a man, especially a boss or master.
meanings.sent1: The bwana of the village was highly respected by all.
meanings.sent2: The workers always addressed their bwana with utmost respect.
meanings.sent3: When the bwana tripped over his own feet, the villagers couldn't help but chuckle.
meanings.sent4: He ruled the company with the authority of a bwana overseeing his kingdom.
meanings.sent5: The image of the wise bwana sitting under the baobab tree was etched in their minds.

meanings.definition: Used as a title of respect for a white person in East Africa.
meanings.sent1: The locals referred to the British explorer as bwana during their conversations.
meanings.sent2: In East Africa, it was customary to address the colonial officials as bwana.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous child jokingly called the visiting tourist 'bwana Snow White'.
meanings.sent4: The title 'bwana' carried a sense of authority and privilege in the colonial era.
meanings.sent5: The word 'bwana' echoed through the savannah, signaling the arrival of the foreigner.

meanings.definition: A term used to address a male authority figure or employer.
meanings.sent1: The young apprentice always sought guidance from his bwana in the workshop.
meanings.sent2: The bwana of the household made sure everything ran smoothly.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous cat seemed to think of itself as the bwana of the house.
meanings.sent4: He was the bwana of the office, making important decisions every day.
meanings.sent5: The loyal dog followed his bwana everywhere, eager to please.
